awd_titl_txt: STEM Pathways Academy at Manchester University
awd_abstract_narration:
Manchester University (MU) will develop the "STEM Pathways Academy", a project to increase the number of students pursuing STEM degrees and the number of professionals in STEM fields. MU will recruit two cohorts of ten academically talented and financially needy first year students majoring in biology, biology-chemistry, or chemistry. Students will experience pedagogical enhancements that engage them in early research, STEM career-focused seminars, tiered mentoring, and opportunities for career exploration. Successful elements of the project will be disseminated to promote strategies that positively impact the retention and success of students in STEM, ultimately increasing the number and diversity of STEM professionals in the field.  

The STEM Pathways Academy will recruit two cohorts of students. These students will experience enhanced curricular components, a tiered mentoring program, and a career-focused seminar series. The curricular enhancements will include problem-based learning, teaching with case studies, flipped classrooms and real-world research projects in classes and labs. The tiered mentoring model will include four levels of mentoring: peers, faculty, industry professionals and alumni. The career-focused seminar courses will involve career exploration, industry and graduate school site visits, and graduate school and career preparation. Project goals will include increased retention (target: 90%), graduation (target: 85% within five years), and postsecondary success in STEM careers or advanced study (target: 100% of graduating scholars). MU will evaluate and advance practices like tiered mentoring and integrated exposure to career options, investigating how these approaches affect STEM career selection and persistence.

por.por_cntn:
The STEM Pathways Academy at Manchester University recruited, enrolled and graduated three (3) cohorts of academically talented, financially needy students from 2017-2023. A total of 42 scholars participated in programming to increase their knowledge of and preparation for STEM careers through evidence-based curricular and support components, a tiered mentoring program, and a career-focused seminar sequence.

We find that STEM Pathways Scholars:

  • Persist in Manchester University STEM majors beyond their first year at higher rates than their peers. 32/42 scholars (76%) remained in a STEM major at Manchester University from their first to second year. This represents a 49% increase over the University?s first-year STEM retention baseline of 51%. The single largest source of student loss from the first to second year (9/10 students) was transfer to another institution.
  • Earn a STEM bachelor's degree from Manchester University at higher rates than their peers. We expect 25/42 scholars to complete their degrees by May 2023, for a cumulative 5-year graduation rate of 62% across all three (3) cohorts. The STEM graduation rate among students who persisted in STEM majors beyond their first year is 78% (25/32 scholars). Both rates represent significant improvement above the University baselines of 43% (retention to graduate in any major) and 33% (retention to graduate with a STEM major).
  • Report that the career-focused coursework and tiered mentoring program provided high value for their own career knowledge and preparation. Graduating scholars participated in exit interviews in which they rated peer mentoring, alumni mentoring, and each of the three (3) career-focused seminars on a scale of 1-4, where 4 represents"greatly contributing" to a student's career knowledge, encouragement to stay in a science major, or preparation for post-graduation plans. The median rating was typically a 3, showing that students broadly appreciated what they gained from mentoring and career-focused seminars. Open-ended comments showed that students felt that peer and alumni mentors exposed them to new perspectives on academic life, as well as potential career opportunities and work-life balance. They believed that the career-focused seminars gave them the opportunity to reflect on the life and work that would suit them best.
  • Do not seek bachelor's-level STEM employment at higher rates than their peers. Of the 25 graduating scholars who completed the STEM Pathways program, 60% reported direct placement in STEM employment or further education. The placement rate is 68% when accounting for students who took an intentional gap year. Students most commonly used their STEM degree as a stepping stone to master?s degrees in STEM and/or STEM-adjacent fields.

Additionally, over the course of this project, the co-PIs built institutional capacity to support all Manchester University STEM majors through several key curricular and co-curricular programs:

  • an investigatory, research-like approach to general biology and general chemistry laboratories, frequently integrating projects;
  • three (3) STEM career-focused courses (first-year writing seminar, sophomore career exploration seminar, junior career exploration seminar)
  • a peer mentoring program at Manchester University for first-year science majors

These curricular components are now available to all STEM majors at Manchester University.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/13/2023
Modified by: Kristen H Short

por.por_txt_cntn:
The STEM Pathways Academy at Manchester University recruited, enrolled and graduated three (3) cohorts of academically talented, financially needy students from 2017-2023. A total of 42 scholars participated in programming to increase their knowledge of and preparation for STEM careers through evidence-based curricular and support components, a tiered mentoring program, and a career-focused seminar sequence.

We find that STEM Pathways Scholars:

Persist in Manchester University STEM majors beyond their first year at higher rates than their peers. 32/42 scholars (76%) remained in a STEM major at Manchester University from their first to second year. This represents a 49% increase over the University?s first-year STEM retention baseline of 51%. The single largest source of student loss from the first to second year (9/10 students) was transfer to another institution.
Earn a STEM bachelor's degree from Manchester University at higher rates than their peers. We expect 25/42 scholars to complete their degrees by May 2023, for a cumulative 5-year graduation rate of 62% across all three (3) cohorts. The STEM graduation rate among students who persisted in STEM majors beyond their first year is 78% (25/32 scholars). Both rates represent significant improvement above the University baselines of 43% (retention to graduate in any major) and 33% (retention to graduate with a STEM major).
Report that the career-focused coursework and tiered mentoring program provided high value for their own career knowledge and preparation. Graduating scholars participated in exit interviews in which they rated peer mentoring, alumni mentoring, and each of the three (3) career-focused seminars on a scale of 1-4, where 4 represents"greatly contributing" to a student's career knowledge, encouragement to stay in a science major, or preparation for post-graduation plans. The median rating was typically a 3, showing that students broadly appreciated what they gained from mentoring and career-focused seminars. Open-ended comments showed that students felt that peer and alumni mentors exposed them to new perspectives on academic life, as well as potential career opportunities and work-life balance. They believed that the career-focused seminars gave them the opportunity to reflect on the life and work that would suit them best.
Do not seek bachelor's-level STEM employment at higher rates than their peers. Of the 25 graduating scholars who completed the STEM Pathways program, 60% reported direct placement in STEM employment or further education. The placement rate is 68% when accounting for students who took an intentional gap year. Students most commonly used their STEM degree as a stepping stone to master?s degrees in STEM and/or STEM-adjacent fields.


Additionally, over the course of this project, the co-PIs built institutional capacity to support all Manchester University STEM majors through several key curricular and co-curricular programs:

an investigatory, research-like approach to      general biology and general chemistry laboratories, frequently integrating      projects;
three (3) STEM career-focused courses (first-year      writing seminar, sophomore career exploration seminar, junior career      exploration seminar)
a peer mentoring program at Manchester University      for first-year science majors


These curricular components are now available to all STEM majors at Manchester University.
